{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014}}
The '''Swiss Art Awards,''' also named the '''Federal Art Competition''', are recognitions that are awarded by the [[Federal Office of Culture]] (FOC) in the name of the [[Swiss|Confederation]].
==History==
The Swiss Art Awards stem from the oldest and most important measure of support to the arts of [[Switzerland]].<ref>FOC. [http://www.letemps.ch/Page/Uuid/1a3357d8-f598-11e3-becf-b7f9645726d2/Le_nouvel_%C3%A9clat_des_Swiss_Art_Awards "Le nouvel éclat des Swiss Art Awards"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021035742/http://www.letemps.ch/Page/Uuid/1a3357d8-f598-11e3-becf-b7f9645726d2/Le_nouvel_%C3%A9clat_des_Swiss_Art_Awards |date=21 October 2014 }} ''www.letemps.ch''</ref> They began in 1898 "as a federal grant for young artists, so as to raise the quality of Swiss Art."<ref>*Lienhard, Pierre-André 1999. "Prix conseillé : 100 ans de Concours fédéral des beaux-arts, 1899–1999", ''''Orrel Füssli'', 15(367)</ref>
The competition and awards have been managed by the FOC since its introduction in 1975.
The grants eventually turned into a competition, changing the name to '''Federal Art Competition''' in 1994<ref>Fleury, Sylvie. "un encouragement visible et mieux doté: les bourses deviennent prix" in " 1999. "Prix conseillé : 100 ans de Concours fédéral des beaux-arts, 1899–1999", ''''Orrel Füssli'', 105(367)</ref> and '''Swiss Art Awards''' since 2014.<ref>Lienhard, Pierre-André 1999. "Prix conseillé : 100 ans de Concours fédéral des beaux-arts, 1899–1999", ''Orrel Füssli'', 15(367)</ref> The '''Swiss Art Awards''' competition and show are held during [[Art Basel]] since 1994.<ref>*FOC {{cite web |url=http://www.bak.admin.ch/aktuelles/01832/02332/05218/index.html?lang=fr |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021225732/http://www.bak.admin.ch/aktuelles/01832/02332/05218/index.html?lang=fr |archivedate=21 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }} ''www.bak.admin.ch''</ref>
Since 2001, three to four '''Swiss Grand Awards for Art/Prix Meret Oppenheim''' are presented, out of a competition run by the Federal Commission for Art (FCA).<ref>Federal administration. Federal Art Commission (FCA){{cite web |url=http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/cf/ko/index_44.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141023212635/http://www.admin.ch/ch/f/cf/ko/index_44.html |archivedate=23 October 2014 |df=dmy-all }} "www.admin.ch"</ref>
==Principals==
Artists, architects, art, and architecture mediators of Swiss origins or based in Switzerland, can submit their application to the FOC. After a first round the FCA chooses a selection of nominees who participate in the show and are considered for the award. Out of these, around ten candidates receive an award for their work along with 25,000 Swiss francs.
The '''Swiss Grand Award for Art/Prix Meret Oppenheim''' on the other hand are awarded by the FCA out of a competition to individuals that have contributed to the study and influence of contemporary Swiss arts and architecture. These distinctions are accompanied with 40,000 Swiss francs to each winner to be used to fund an important project.<ref>FOC. {{cite web |url=http://www.bak.admin.ch/kulturschaffen/04163/04164/04165/index.html?lang=fr |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2018-03-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170822012402/http://www.bak.admin.ch/kulturschaffen/04163/04164/04165/index.html?lang=fr |archivedate=22 August 2017 |df=dmy-all }} "Swiss Grand Art Awards / Prix Meret Oppenheim, "www.bak.admin.ch"</ref>
==Notes and references== {{Reflist|2}}
{{Portal bar|Arts|Switzerland}}
[[Category:Swiss awards]] [[Category:Arts awards]]
{{award-stub}}

page.title: TNA Impact!'s move to Monday nights

revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Use mdy dates|date=October 2017}} In March 2010, [[professional wrestling]] promotion [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) moved their weekly television program, ''[[Impact! (TV series)|Impact!]]'', from airing on Thursdays to airing Monday nights. In doing so, TNA placed ''Impact!'' in direct competition with [[WWE|World Wrestling Entertainment]]'s (WWE) flagship program ''[[WWE Raw|Monday Night Raw]]''. It drew comparisons to the [[Monday Night Wars]], in which defunct wrestling promotion [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW) program ''[[WCW Nitro|Nitro]]'' went head-to-head with ''Raw'' in a battle for higher [[Nielsen ratings]] each week from 1995 to 2001; this led ''Impact!''{{'}}s move to sometimes be called "The New Monday Night Wars". The move was spurred by the signing of [[Hulk Hogan]] and [[Eric Bischoff]], two central figures of the original Monday Night War. Unlike the ratings battle with WCW, TNA never gained traction against WWE, despite initially setting record high ratings for ''Impact!''. ''Impact!'' returned to its Thursday night timeslot after declining ratings in May, less than two months after the move. {{DISPLAYTITLE:TNA ''Impact!'''s move to Monday nights}}
Chart of ''Impact!'' and ''Raw'' ratings
{|style="text-align:left" |- |{{legend|#ff6565|''Raw'' lead}} || {{legend|#ffff65|Tie}} |- |{{legend|#6565ff|''Impact!'' lead}} || {{legend|#65b265|Ratings unavailable}} |- | |} {| |- | {|class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:8px 0 0;" |- !Date !! ''Raw'' !! ''Impact!'' |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-01-04 || 3.6 || 1.5 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-03-08 || 3.4 || 0.98 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-03-15 || 3.71 || 0.84 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-03-22 || 3.2 || 0.86 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-03-29 || 3.7 || 0.62 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-04-05 || 3.15 || 0.9 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-04-12 || 3.24 || 0.8 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-04-19 || 3.05 || 0.95 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-04-26 || 3.3 || 0.5 |- style="background:#ff6565" |2010-05-03 || 3.05 || 0.8 |} |}
==Background and first Monday ''Impact!''== On October 27, 2009, [[Hulk Hogan]] announced that he and [[Eric Bischoff]] had signed with [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) in a press conference held at [[Madison Square Garden]]. TNA President [[Dixie Carter (wrestling)|Dixie Carter]] stated "Our goal is to become the world's biggest professional wrestling company. Hulk defines professional wrestling and we look forward to partnering with him in a variety of ways as we continue to grow TNA globally."{{cite web |author=Matt Fowler |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/10/28/hulk-hogan-signs-with-tna |title=Hulk Hogan Signs With TNA |publisher=[[IGN]] |date=October 27, 2009 |accessdate=October 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028202018/http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/10/28/hulk-hogan-signs-with-tna |archivedate=October 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} [[File:Hulk Hogan July 2010.jpg|thumb|left|190px|Hulk Hogan joined TNA in late 2009]] During an appearance on [[Paramount Network|Spike]]'s presentation of ''[[The Ultimate Fighter: Heavyweights Finale]]'' on December 5, Hogan announced that ''[[TNA Impact!|Impact!]]'', which normally aired on Thursdays, would go head to head with [[World Wrestling Entertainment]]'s (WWE) ''[[WWE Raw|Raw]]'' on Monday January 4 in a three-hour live broadcast on Spike.{{cite news|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/wrestling/2760057/Hulk-Hogan-to-make-TNA-debut-live-on-Monday-January-4-up-against-Raw.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091209022331/http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/wrestling/2760057/Hulk-Hogan-to-make-TNA-debut-live-on-Monday-January-4-up-against-Raw.html|archivedate=December 9, 2009|deadurl=yes|work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|first=Simon|last=Rothstein|title=Monday Night Wars to return|date=December 6, 2009|accessdate=October 28, 2017}} Hogan was a top talent in [[World Championship Wrestling]] (WCW), which Bischoff was an executive of, when the company debuted a program in 1995, ''[[WCW Nitro|Nitro]]'', to compete with ''Raw'' in a ratings battle called the [[Monday Night Wars]].{{cite web|url=http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/08/hulk-hogan-nwo-monday-night-wars|title=Hulk Hogan 'prayed to God' the WWE wouldn't lose the Monday Night War|work=[[USA Today]]|last=Schwartz|first=Nick|date=August 26, 2014|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107003855/http://ftw.usatoday.com/2014/08/hulk-hogan-nwo-monday-night-wars|archivedate=November 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The January 4 show would be the first time since ''Nitro''{{'}}s last episode in March 2001 that two major wrestling promotions would go head-to-head in a Monday night ratings competition. WWE countered by announcing the return of Bret Hart, who had not appeared in WWE since the [[Montreal Screwjob]] in 1997.{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/12/16/bret-hart-signs-with-the-wwe|title=Bret Hart Signs With WWE|publisher=IGN|last=Fowler|first=Matt|date=December 16, 2009|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201840/http://www.ign.com/articles/2009/12/16/bret-hart-signs-with-the-wwe|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Leading up to the show, TNA President Dixie Carter stated that while Spike was not expecting ''Impact!'' to beat ''Raw'' in the ratings, it would be considered a success if they managed to at least maintain their usual Thursday night ''Impact!'' rating.{{cite web|url=http://www.pwnewsnow.com/news.php?subaction=showfull&id=1262665575&archive=&start_from=&ucat=6|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100210115821/http://www.pwnewsnow.com/news.php?subaction=showfull&id=1262665575&archive=&start_from=&ucat=6|title=TNA's Dixie Carter Says SpikeTV Not Expecting Big Ratings for Live Impact|work=Pwnewsnow.com|date=January 4, 2010|accessdate=February 2, 2012|archivedate=January 4, 2010|last=Michaels|first=Chris}} Spike president [[Kevin Kay]] also announced there were plans to air ''Impact!'' on Mondays quarterly through 2010 and added that if the ratings proved successful on January 4, it could be moved to Monday nights permanently.{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/TNA/article1009364.shtml|title=TNA Impact to air more frequently on Monday nights, Spike TV executive says he's not opposed to moving the show permanently|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|last=Powell|first=Jason|date=December 19, 2009|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201138/https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/TNA/article1009364.shtml|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} By signing with TNA, Bischoff and Hogan were paired with writer [[Vince Russo]], whom they had conflicted with in WCW and had not worked with since they departed the company after [[Bash At The Beach 2000#2000|Bash at the Beach 2000]]. According to Russo, the three met together and worked out their differences before the January 4 show.{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/InterviewHighlights/article10010103.shtml|title=Vince Russo says Vince McMahon made a mistake when he promoted Stephanie McMahon to head of WWE creative, comments on his working relationships with Hulk Hogan and Eric Bischoff|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|date=February 3, 2010|accessdate=November 4, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107012302/https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/InterviewHighlights/article10010103.shtml|archivedate=November 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The Monday night ''Impact!'' featured the returns of [[Scott Hall]], [[Sean Waltman]], [[Sting (wrestler)|Sting]], [[Jeff Jarrett]], [[Jeff Hardy]], and the debuts of [[Ric Flair]], [[Sean Morley]], [[The Nasty Boys]], [[Orlando Jordan]] and [[Bubba the Love Sponge]] in addition to Hogan and Bischoff.{{cite web|url=https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TV_Reports_9/article_37861.shtml|title=Keller's TNA Impact Live Report 1/4: Jeff Hardy, NWO reunion, Hulk Hogan, TNA Knockout Title match, more surprises – ongoing coverage|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|last=Keller|first=Wade|date=January 4, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|authorlink=Wade Keller|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201548/https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TV_Reports_9/article_37861.shtml|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} On ''Raw'', Bret Hart confronted [[Vince McMahon]] and [[Shawn Michaels]] for the first time in thirteen years.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-wrestling-results/wwe-raw-results/2526-raw-results-1-4-10/|title=Raw Results – 1/4/10|work=WrestleView|last=Nemer|first=Paul|date=January 4, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201327/http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-wrestling-results/wwe-raw-results/2526-raw-results-1-4-10/|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} [[File:Bret vs HBK Jan 4 2010.jpg|right|thumb|[[Bret Hart]] confronts [[Shawn Michaels]] on January 4, 2010]] The ratings showed that ''Raw'' came out on top, averaging 5.6 million viewers while ''Impact!'' averaged 2.2 million viewers. The show peaked with three million viewers for the Hulk Hogan segment but then the viewership declined towards the end of the show to near 2.2 million viewers, the replay on January 7, 2010, garnered a 0.9 rating thus giving TNA a combined viewership range of 3.5–4.5 million viewers.{{cite web |author=Paul Nemer |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/2407-rating-for-1-7-tna-impact-replay/ |title=Rating for 1/7 TNA Impact replay – Wrestling News and Results, WWE News, TNA News, ROH News |website=WrestleView |date=January 8, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161026022305/http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/2407-rating-for-1-7-tna-impact-replay/ |archivedate=October 26, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/wrestling/blog/2010/01/ratings_news_for_mondays_raw_tna_impact.html|title=Ring Posts: Ratings news for Monday’s Raw, TNA Impact|work=[[The Baltimore Sun]]|last=Eck|first=Kevin|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109095218/http://weblogs.baltimoresun.com/sports/wrestling/blog/2010/01/ratings_news_for_mondays_raw_tna_impact.html|deadurl=yes|archivedate=January 9, 2010|date=January 5, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017}} However, despite not beating ''Raw'' in the ratings, TNA managed to set a new record for ''Impact!'', beating the previous one of 1.97 million viewers, and thus gaining the confidence of Spike representatives.{{cite news|url=https://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_37908.shtml|title=TNA News: Ratings are in for last night's Impact – TNA draws highest audience ever, huge quarter-hour for Hulk Hogan|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|first=James|last=Caldwell|date=January 5, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028145456/https://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_37908.shtml|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ==Move to Mondays== [[File:Eric Bischoff 2010.jpg|thumb|left|Bischoff at a TNA event in July 2010]] On March 8, 2010, ''Impact!'' moved to Monday nights at 9 pm EST to compete head-to-head with ''Raw''. Eric Bischoff was once again competing on the opposite side of Vince McMahon's WWE and in an interview with Bubba the Love Sponge, he said that he believed "history is repeating itself". This new "war" began in much the same way as the original did; with TNA relying on established wrestlers, including former WWE talent, and with the company being led by Hulk Hogan and Eric Bischoff. WWE spokesman Robert Zimmerman responded to TNA's move by saying "We're not too concerned. We're in good shape."{{cite web |url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/1312-tna-moving-to-monday-nights-in-march/ |title=TNA moving to Monday nights in March |work=WrestleView |last=Martin |first=Adam |date=February 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028145633/http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/1312-tna-moving-to-monday-nights-in-march/ |archivedate=October 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} Bischoff and Russo each stated that TNA were not focused on beating WWE in the ratings straight away, but rather gaining a significant share of their audience and growing TNA's own audience.{{cite web |url=https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39347.shtml |title=TNA/WWE News: Eric Bischoff and Vince Russo talk head-to-head goals vs. WWE Raw on Monday nights |work=Pro Wrestling Torch |last=Caldwell |first=James |date=February 24, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201550/https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39347.shtml |archivedate=October 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} [[File:RVDTNAChamp1.JPG|thumb|[[Rob Van Dam]] won the [[TNA World Heavyweight Championship]] on the highest rated episode in April]] On the March 8, 2010, ''Raw'' beat ''Impact!'' with a 3.4 rating which equated to approximately 5.1 million viewers, while ''Impact!'' did a 0.98 with 1.4 million viewers; the replay of the show on Thursdays did 1.0, getting TNA a combined audience of 2.7 million viewers.{{cite web |last=Caldwell |first=James |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39841.shtml |title=TNA News: More TNA Impact ratings data – Spike TV reports 5.6 million people sampled 3/8 Impact |website=Pro Wrestling Torch |date=March 15, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201324/https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39841.shtml |archivedate=October 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} The following week, the March 15 episode of ''Impact!'' scored its lowest rating since November 2006 with a .84 rating.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39891.shtml|title=TNA Impact draws lowest rating since 2006|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 16, 2010|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=March 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323093708/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39891.shtml|archivedate=March 23, 2010|df=mdy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39893.shtml|title=Inside the quarter-hour ratings for TNA Impact|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 16, 2010|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=March 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322235627/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39893.shtml|archivedate=March 22, 2010|df=mdy-all}} No quarter-hour segment of ''Impact!'' reached past the previous week's overall rating. The broadcast lost 15% of the audience it opened with, going from a .87 opening quarter-hour to a .72 in the [[A.J. Styles]] versus [[Jeff Hardy]] main event. ''Impact!'' averaged 1.1 million viewers, an overall decrease of 21.4% in viewership from the previous week.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39889.shtml|title=Impact ratings are in|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 16, 2010|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=March 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100323093703/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_39889.shtml|archivedate=March 23, 2010|df=mdy-all}} ''Raw'' scored a 3.71 rating and averaged 5.60 million viewers, an overall increase of 10% in viewership from the previous week. The broadcast's first hour was the most viewed first hour since August 24, 2009, while the second was the most viewed second hour since January 4, 2010.{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_39890.shtml|title=WWE Raw ratings are in for "Stone Cold" Raw|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 16, 2010|website=Pro Wrestling Torch|accessdate=March 16, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322192030/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_39890.shtml|archivedate=March 22, 2010|df=mdy-all}} On March 22, six days before [[WrestleMania XXVI]], ''Raw'' scored a 3.2 and ''Impact!'' scored a 0.86. ''Raw''{{'}}s rating was down more than one million viewers, equating to about 20%. Ratings for ''Impact!'' had improved slightly over the last week as they promoted a Career vs. Career match between [[Jeff Jarrett]] and [[Mick Foley]].{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/12663|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100322194114/http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/12663 |title=Last night's ratings are in |date=March 22, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2017 |archivedate=March 22, 2010 |work=[[Wrestling Observer Newsletter]] |deadurl=yes |df= }} The night after WrestleMania XXVI, ''Raw'' scored a 3.7 rating, up from last week, and ''Impact!'' scored a 0.62.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/13161-final-4-5-tna-impact-rating/|title=Final 4/5 TNA Impact rating|last=Nember|first=Paul|date=April 5, 2010|accessdate=October 29, 2017|work=WrestleView|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171030002926/http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/13161-final-4-5-tna-impact-rating/|archivedate=October 30, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Spike executives announced the April 5 live ''Impact!'' would air an hour earlier than ''Raw'' due to competition from an NCAA college basketball tournament.{{cite web|url=https://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_40125.shtml|title=TNA News: Why TNA Impact is moving up one hour on April 5, Dixie Carter confirms via Twitter|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=March 25, 2010|accessdate=February 25, 2017|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028150027/https://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_40125.shtml|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The April 5 episode of ''Raw'' lost 14% of their viewers with a 3.15 rating, while ''Impact!'' scored a 0.9 rating, their highest rating since the March 15 episode, gaining a 33% in total viewers as they aired Kurt Angle vs. Mr. Anderson in a [[ladder match]].{{cite web|url=https://superluchas.com/detalles-del-rating-del-5-de-abril-2010-el-mas-bajo-rating-del-ano-para-raw/|title=Detalles del rating del 5 de abril 2010 – El más bajo rating del año para Raw|last=Ocampo|first=Jose|date=April 7, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|work=[[Super Luchas]]|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201439/https://superluchas.com/detalles-del-rating-del-5-de-abril-2010-el-mas-bajo-rating-del-ano-para-raw/|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} After better ratings for the April 5 episode of ''Impact!'', TNA decided to start ''Impact!'' at the 8:00 p.m. ET time slot permanently.{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/TNA/article10011246.shtml|title=Major TNA News: TNA Impact time slot officially changed, weekly replay added|last=Powell|first=Jason|date=April 7, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029012451/https://prowrestling.net/artman/publish/TNA/article10011246.shtml|archivedate=October 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}} The April 12 episode of ''Raw'' made a comeback with a 3.24 rating, while the taped ''Impact!'' scored a 0.8 rating managing to keep most of their audience.{{cite web|url=https://superluchas.com/ratings-wwe-vs-tna-12-abril-2010/|title=Ratings WWE vs TNA (12 abril 2010)|last=Ocampo|first=Jose|date=April 13, 2010|accessdate=November 7, 2017|work=[[Super Luchas]]|language=Spanish|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107170512/https://superluchas.com/ratings-wwe-vs-tna-12-abril-2010/|archivedate=November 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Then on April 19, the night after [[Lockdown (2010)|TNA Lockdown]], ''Raw'' scored a 3.05 rating, their lowest score in two years, while ''Impact!'' scored a 0.95 rating, their highest score since April 5 as they featured a [[TNA World Heavyweight Championship]] match between [[Rob Van Dam]] and A.J. Styles.{{cite web |author= |url=https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_40787.shtml |title=TNA News: Inside the quarter-hour ratings for Monday night's TNA Impact |work=Pro Wrestling Torch |last=Caldwell |first=James |date=April 20, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028201625/https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_40787.shtml |archivedate=October 28, 2017 |df=mdy-all }} On April 26, ''Raw'' aired the [[2010 WWE draft]], and scored a 3.3 rating, while ''Impact!'' lost 48% of their audience with a 0.5 rating.{{cite web|url=https://prowrestling.net/article.php?WWE-Raw-vs.-TNA-Impact-ratings-Preliminary-numbers-look-horrible-for-TNA-updated-11504|title=WWE Raw vs. TNA Impact ratings: Preliminary numbers look horrible for TNA (updated)|last=Powell|first=Jason|date=April 27, 2010|accessdate=October 29, 2017|work=Pro Wrestling Dot Net|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171029174105/https://prowrestling.net/article.php?WWE-Raw-vs.-TNA-Impact-ratings-Preliminary-numbers-look-horrible-for-TNA-updated-11504|archivedate=October 29, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ''Impact!'' moved back to Thursday nights starting with the May 13 show. On the final battle between ''Raw'' and ''Impact!'', ''Raw'' drew a 3.05 and ''Impact!'' drew a 0.8 rating gaining a 37.5% in total viewers. The replay ratings of most of Monday night episodes were sufficient for survival but showed that the average audience is some two million viewers that prefer to watch on Thursdays.{{cite web |last=Caldwell |first=James |url=http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_41007.shtml |title=TNA News: TNA Impact replay ratings – viewership for Spike TV replay last night |website=Pro Wrestling Torch |date=April 30, 2010 |accessdate=January 2, 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055713/http://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_41007.shtml |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_41077.shtml|title=TNA News: TNA rebranding Impact on Thursday nights; "Reaction" start date announced in press release on Thursday move|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=May 3, 2010|accessdate=February 25, 2017|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303175515/http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_41077.shtml|archivedate=March 3, 2016|df=mdy-all}} [[File:Dixie Carter on the mic.jpg|thumb|TNA President [[Dixie Carter (wrestling)|Dixie Carter]] in 2010]] In a press release, Spike TV's Senior Vice President of Sports and Specials, Brian J. Diamond, said: "The fans have spoken and with their input we have determined the best time slot to maximize the TNA audience is on Thursday nights where we are confident it will be among the most-watched shows with young men". In the same announcement, TNA president [[Dixie Carter (wrestling)|Dixie Carter]] was quoted as saying, "Our fans made it clear that they preferred the Thursday night time period. By moving to Thursdays, this is a win/win opportunity for both TNA and the fans. We are looking forward to delivering what the fans are asking for." ==Reception and legacy== ''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]'' described the move as one of many gambles TNA has taken during their history, but wrote that it "turned out disastrously."{{cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/the-renaissance-of-tna-wrestling-and-why-it-might-be-doomed-anyway|title=The Renaissance of TNA Wrestling and Why It Might Be Doomed Anyway|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|last=Breihan|first=Tom|date=September 23, 2014|accessdate=February 25, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226133005/https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/the-renaissance-of-tna-wrestling-and-why-it-might-be-doomed-anyway|archivedate=February 26, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ''Impact!'' ratings dropped seven percent from 2009's 1.14 average, finishing 2010 at 1.06. ''WrestleView'' ascribed the drop to the "disastrous decision" to run opposite ''Raw''.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/20306-tna-impact-average-rating-down-in-2010/|title=TNA Impact average rating down in 2010|work=WrestleView|last=Nemer|first=Paul|date=January 17, 2011|accessdate=October 30, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107030714/http://www.wrestleview.com/tna-news/20306-tna-impact-average-rating-down-in-2010/|archivedate=November 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Although the move failed to boost ratings for TNA, James Caldwell of ''Pro Wrestling Torch'' attributed a six percent drop in ''Raw'' ratings (from 3.69 to 3.47) to competition from ''Impact!''{{cite web|url=https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_40999.shtml|title=WWE News: Raw TV ratings 2010 vs. 2009 comparison – Analysis of ratings through first four months, TNA Impact's effect|work=Pro Wrestling Torch|last=Caldwell|first=James|date=April 30, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171028145316/https://www.pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/WWE_News_3/article_40999.shtml|archivedate=October 28, 2017|df=mdy-all}} At the end of 2010, the "New Monday Night Wars" received the annual [[WrestleCrap]] [[Gooker Award]], which honors the worst events in wrestling.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestlecrap.com/inductions/the-new-monday-night-wars-2010-gooker-award-winner/ |title=The New Monday Night Wars: 2010 Gooker Award Winner |last=Reynolds |first=R.D. |publisher=[[WrestleCrap]]|date=October 5, 2016|accessdate=February 24, 2017 |authorlink=R.D. Reynolds}} By July 2011, nearly all of the new talents brought in for ''Impact!''{{'}}s initial Monday launch had left the company, with the exceptions of [[Ric Flair]] (who left the following year) and [[Jeff Hardy]] (who left in 2017).{{cite web|url=http://www.pwinsider.com/article/59773/orlando-jordantna-update.html?p=1|title=Orlando Jordan-TNA Update|work=Pro Wrestling Insider|last=Johnson|first=Mike|date=July 12, 2011|accessdate=February 25, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170226131616/http://www.pwinsider.com/article/59773/orlando-jordantna-update.html?p=1|archivedate=February 26, 2017|df=mdy-all}} Hulk Hogan departed TNA in October 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/the-squared-circle/Hulk-Hogan-no-longer-under-contract-with-TNA-Wrestling.html|title=Hulk Hogan no longer under contract with TNA Wrestling|last=Johnson|first=Vaughn|work=[[Philly.com]]|date=October 2, 2013|accessdate=July 18, 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150721155925/http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/the-squared-circle/Hulk-Hogan-no-longer-under-contract-with-TNA-Wrestling.html|archivedate=July 21, 2015|df=mdy-all}} Eric Bischoff was sent home from TNA in October 2013 and his contract expired in early 2014. When asked about positive memories from his time in TNA, Bischoff stated, "I don’t have any."{{cite web|url=http://pwinsider.com/article/103824/eric-bischoff-suing-tna-wrestling.html?p=1|title=Eric Bischoff suing TNA Wrestling|last=Ryder|first=Ryan|date=August 4, 2016|accessdate=October 30, 2017|work=Pro Wrestling Insider|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107114242/https://www.pwinsider.com/article/103824/eric-bischoff-suing-tna-wrestling.html?p=1|archivedate=November 7, 2017|df=mdy-all}} In the tenth anniversary reprint of [[R.D. Reynolds]] and [[Brian Alvarez]]'s ''Death of WCW'', the authors compared the move to the original Monday Night Wars. They wrote that TNA did not have the audience that WCW did when they moved to initiate the Monday Night Wars, pointing out that ''[[WCW Saturday Night]]'' typically did better than WWE shows did in the weekend timeslots. Reynolds and Alvarez also wrote that TNA did not have the financial resources that WCW did and that WWE was not "asleep at the wheel" as they were in 1995.{{cite book |first1= R.D. |first2=Bryan |last1= Reynolds |last2=Alvarez |year= 2014 |title= The Death of WCW: 10th Anniversary Edition of the Bestselling Classic — Revised and Expanded |publisher= ECW Press |isbn= 978-1770411753|authorlink1=R.D. Reynolds|authorlink2=Bryan Alvarez}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * {{cite web | url = http://www.sportingnews.com/wwe/news/tna-impact-wrestling-latest-anthem-entertainment-monday-night-wars-eric-bischoff-wcw/clk999ne63de1jtszufpgf341 | title = Monday Night Wrong: TNA attempts to revive the Monday Night Wars | last = Keith | first = Brian | work = [[Sporting News]] | accessdate=February 25, 2018 | date = November 6, 2017}} {{Total Nonstop Action Wrestling}} {{WWE}} [[Category:2010s in American television]] [[Category:History of professional wrestling]] [[Category:Mass media rivalries]] [[Category:Spike (TV network)]] [[Category:Impact Wrestling television programs]] [[Category:WWE Raw]]

page.title: The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne

revision.comment: +[[Category:Paintings of gods]]; +[[Category:Angels in art]]; +[[Category:Birds in art]]; +[[Category:Lions in art]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:The Four and Twenty Elders (William Blake).jpg|thumb|''The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne'', c. 1803–5. [[William Blake]], [[Tate]]. 354 x 293 mm.]] '''''The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne''''' is a pencil drawing and [[Watercolor painting|watercolour]] on paper by the English [[English poetry|poet]], [[Painting|painter]] and [[printmaker]] [[William Blake]]. Created circa 1803–1805, the drawing has been held in London's [[Tate]] gallery since 1949. It is likely a visionary and hallucinatory summary of scenes from Chapters 4 and 5Although some imagery from Chapter 6 is also described in this work, of the [[Book of Revelation]] when the throne of God was presented to the prophet [[John of Patmos|Saint John the Divine]].[http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/exhibitions/gothicnightmares/rooms/room7.htm Fuseli, Blake and the Romantic Imagination]. [[Tate]], 2006. Retrieved on November 05, 2008. Saint John described the scene, :before the throne there was a sea of glass like unto crystal... round about... were four beasts full of eyes... The four and twenty elders fall down before him... and worship him that liveth for ever and ever.[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?workid=1149&tabview=work The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne: Description]. [[Tate]]. Retrieved on November 05, 2008. Blake's depiction was created as part of a commission of biblical watercolours for his friend and patronIngram, Allan. "Patterns of Madness in the Eighteenth Century". Liverpool: Liverpool University Press, 1998. 216. {{ISBN|0-85323-992-4}} Thomas Butts. The artist began to work on Butts's series around 1800. For stylistic reasons—including the use of pencil instead of pen and ink—it is generally believed by scholars that Blake began work on the piece sometime in 1803.'It is listed in Blake's account with Thomas Butts of 3 March 1806, apparently as having been delivered on 12 May 1805'. From the Tate catalogue. Paintings and drawings from the series are typically characterised by intense displays of colour and ''The [[Four and Twenty Elders]]'' is generally held as one of the most vivid examples of Blake's output from the period.Myrone, 109 [[File:Sketch for The Four and Twenty Elders (Blake).jpg|150px|left|thumb|Blake's ''Sketch for The Four and Twenty Elders'' (pencil on paper, 488 x 389 mm), although loosely drawn, anticipates the symmetrical architecture of the finished piece."[https://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?cgroupid=999999961&workid=1067&searchid=9041&tabview=work Sketch for 'The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne']". Tate. Retrieved on November 05, 2008.]] In this watercolour, Blake arranges the various elements and characters from the biblical text in a highly symmetrical and organised manner. God is pictured sitting on his throne at the center of the panel and portrayed as an ancient figure with a long and broad white beard, dressed in red clothing. The Deity holds a book or scroll in his right hand, according to scripture, "written within and on the backside, sealed with [[seven seals]]',Revelation 5.1 while his left hand is raised in a gesture of [[benediction]] and blessing.Robertson, 68 His throne is enclosed by a rainbow which radiates from below a pointed [[Gothic architecture|Gothic arch]] formed from the wings of angels. Before the throne is a slain lamb, "having seven horns and seven eyes, which are the [[seven Spirits of God]] sent forth into all the earth".Revelation 5.6 The lamb's seven horns are represented by seven spikes fanned above his corpse, while the seven [[cherub]]ic heads beneath him allude to the "seven Spirits of God". Each cherub is crowned by a tongued flame, a reference to the "seven lamps of fire" described in Revelation 4.5. In Revelation, Saint John wrote, :And round about the throne were four and twenty seats: and upon the seats I saw four and twenty elders sitting, clothed in white raiment: and they had on their heads crowns of gold. A row of twelve white-clad bearded figures float on either side of the Deity, although only four figures from each row are visible to the viewer of the panel. Each figure bends towards God, in adoration, to lay a golden crown at his feet. Above the head of God are the Four Beasts, "full of eyes before and behind".Revelation 4.6 Above and to the left of God perches the Eagle, opposite of whom is the Lion. Both are portrayed with the pallor of death and both are situated beneath the distorted heads of monstrous birds and animals. The Ox and Angel are positioned behind the throne and peer outwards, according to the Blake collector W. Graham Robertson, "dimly [and] half hidden in the pale crimson and violet rays which emanate from the central figure, and shoot up to meet and be absorbed in the {{sic|?|hide=y|over-|arching}} rainbow."Robertson, 69 There are many uses of numerical symbolism in ''The Four and Twenty Elders'', and according to the Blake scholar [[Martin Myrone]], "the way, as with [Blake's] ''[[Ezekiel's Wheels]]'', that multiples and unities meld into one another, underpinned Blakes own poetic conceptions." The painting was first passed to Butts and upon his death was bequeathed to his son. In 1906, it passed to W. Graham Robertson for £6,720. Following Robertson's passing, the panel was sold at auction at [[Christie's]] to the Tate in 1949, with financial assistance from the [[The Art Fund|National Art Collections Fund]].[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?cgroupid=-1&workid=1149&searchid=false&roomid=false&tabview=text&texttype=8 The Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne: Catalogue]. Tate. Retrieved on November 05, 2008."[http://www.artfund.org/tag/William+Blake Art Saved]". [[The Art Fund]]. Retrieved on November 05, 2008. ==Notes== {{reflist|30em}} ==References== * Myrone, Martin. ''The Blake Book''. London: [[Tate]], 2007. {{ISBN|978-1-85437-727-2}} * Raine, Kathleen. ''William Blake''. London: Thames and Hudson, 1988 [1951]. {{ISBN|0-500-20107-2}} * Robertson, W. Graham. ''The Blake Collection of W. Graham Robertson''. London: Faber and Faber Limited, 1952. ==External links== * [http://www.tate.org.uk/britain/exhibitions/gothicnightmares/rooms/room7.htm Fuseli, Blake and the Romantic Imagination, 15 February-1 May 2006, Tate]
{{William Blake|art}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Four and Twenty Elders Casting their Crowns before the Divine Throne}} [[Category:1805 paintings]] [[Category:Art by William Blake]] [[Category:Collection of the Tate galleries]] [[Category:Watercolor paintings]] [[Category:Paintings depicting Book of Revelation themes]] [[Category:Paintings of gods]] [[Category:Angels in art]] [[Category:Birds in art]] [[Category:Lions in art]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
[[Image:RAFlogo.jpg|thumb|''Logo of The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship'']] '''The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship''' was founded by the [[Stuckism|Stuckist]] painter [[Odysseus Yakoumakis]] on September 2004, as the first, and currently the only, Greek group of [[Stuckism|Stuckism International]]. It has an international membership.
==History== [[Odysseus Yakoumakis]] discovered Stuckism in July, 2004, while surfing the net, and saw in it an antidote to what he deems "the ailments of the contemporary Greek 'artscape'".<ref>This issue is taken up in Yakoumis' article, "The Academic Provincialism of contemporary Greek Art and its proposed Stuckist remedy", to be presented by him at the first Stuckist international symposium [http://www.student.livjm.ac.uk/lsaiwyli/TheTriumphOfStuckism/index.html ''The Triumph of Stuckism''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060414172054/http://www.student.livjm.ac.uk/lsaiwyli/TheTriumphOfStuckism/index.html |date=2006-04-14 }} in Liverpool, England</ref> He contacted [[Charles Thomson (artist)|Charles Thomson]], the London founder of Stuckism, and a few days later founded The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship. He conceived this as a "Greek version of Stuckism, an antidote to contemporary Greek art's [[Parochialism|provincialism]], [[sectarianism]] and servile importation of [[post-modernism]]". He developed the concept of "Romantic Stuckism", that is of "Stuckism with a good injection of [[Eleatic]] and [[Platonic philosophy]], oriented rather towards encouraging each artist to pursue his/her genuinely personal artistic vision rather, than towards pointless polemics against the reactionary official art-establishment". He published the first two Romantic Stuckist theoretical texts on the Fellowship's website.
At that stage he was the Fellowship's only fellow and, as far as he knew, the only artist in Greece aware of the Stuckist movement. He contacted other fine artists in Athens, but described the reactions he got as "ranging from a tepid 'academic curiosity' to a sheer lack of interest or even, occasionally, to a politely concealed hostility." He was however contacted by artists from overseas and accepted them into the Fellowship. The first to apply was [http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett], a painter living in London and founder of the Ealing Stuckists group. Shortly after, followed the painter and etcher [http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah] from Canada, and the painter and etcher [http://www.artworksbyanthe.com/ Anthe] (who is of Greek descent) from the US.
==Under the Cover of Romantic Anonymity== Yakoumakis determined that Stuckism should, nevertheless, be brought "in the flesh" before the eyes of the Greek fine arts community, and organised the first Stuckist event in Greece, titled ''Under the Cover of Romantic Anonymity'', announced for May 14 of 2010 at the Ash-In-Art Gallery, Athens, Greece.
In parallel with the show, the new book by Odysseus Yakoumakis will be featured, titled "Leaflets from the Wilderness (a case study about the artscape in nouveau-Greece and many other lands)" (Ash-In-Art Publications).
Stuckist artists taking part include: *[http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah] *[http://www.artworksbyanthe.com/ ANTHE] *[http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett] *Odysseus Yakoumakis Guest artists participating are: *[http://www.song-rays.com/about.html Ray Wilkins] *Lefteris Yakoumakis *Vasilis Selimas *Nickos Delijannis
==Footnotes== <references />
==See also==
*[[Stuckism]] *[[Remodernism]] *[[Odysseus Yakoumakis]]
==References== *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/PostModernismCritique_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "A Romantic & Anonymous (nonetheless signed) Critique of Post Modernism"] *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/Manifesto_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "The Romantic Anonymous Manifesto"] *[http://www.odysseus-art.net/RAF/GreekAcademicProvincialism_EN.html Odysseus Yakoumakis, "The Academic Provincialism of contemporary Greek Art and its proposed Stuckist remedy"]
==External links== * [http://www.stuckism.com Stuckist web site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060424165552/http://www.stuckism-athens.org/ The Romantic Anonymous Fellowship official site] * [http://www.rosaspada.com/ Odysseus Yakoumakis official site] * [http://www.ianjburkett.co.uk/ Ian J. Burkett's official site] * [http://www.ilaniaabileah.com/ Ilania Abileah's official site] * [http://www.anthe.com/ ANTHE's official site]
{{Stuckism}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Romantic Anonymous Fellowship}} [[Category:Greek contemporary art]] [[Category:International artist groups and collectives]] [[Category:Art movements]] [[Category:Stuckism]]

{{infobox book | name = The Scroll of the Dead | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Scroll of the Dead.jpg| caption = | author = [[David Stuart Davies]] | cover_artist = | country = [[United Kingdom]] | language = English | series = | genre = Adventure, Mystery | published = 1998
13 November 2009 (Titan Books) | media_type = Novel | pages = 208 | isbn = 1848564937 |ISBN_note = (first edition) | dewey= | congress= | oclc= }} '''''The Scroll of the Dead''''' is a 1998 adventure mystery [[pastiche]] novel written by [[David Stuart Davies]], featuring [[Sherlock Holmes]] and [[Dr. Watson|Dr. John Watson]] as they investigate a theft from the British Museum with ties to the Black Arts. ==Plot== After Holmes and Watson attend a bogus seance to unmask a phony psychic, they are called upon to investigate a murder and the theft of a scroll from the British Museum. As it turns out, this is but the first key towards uncovering a mysterious Egyptian tomb, and within it, a papyrus that may hold the power of eternal life. ==Reprints== [[Titan Books]] reprinted the book in 2009, under the title of ''The Further Adventures of Sherlock Holmes: The Scroll of the Dead'' as part of its ''Further Adventures'' series, which collects a number of noted Holmesian pastiches. ==See also== * [[Sherlock Holmes pastiches]] ==External links== *[http://titanbooks.com/the-further-adventures-of-sherlock-holmes-the-scroll-of-the-dead-4524/ ''The Scroll of the Dead''] at [[Titan Books]] {{Sherlock Holmes by others}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scroll of the Dead, The}} [[Category:1998 novels]] [[Category:England in fiction]] [[Category:Ancient Egypt in popular culture]] [[Category:Ancient Egypt in fiction]] [[Category:Sherlock Holmes pastiches]] [[Category:Sherlock Holmes novels]]

page.title: The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra

revision.text:
{{about|the composition by Benjamin Britten|the television series|Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra}} {{italic title}}{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}}
'''''The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra''''' is a 1945 musical composition by [[Benjamin Britten]] with a subtitle '''''Variations and [[Fugue]] on a Theme of [[Henry Purcell|Purcell]]'''''. It was based on the second movement, "Rondeau", of the ''[[Abdelazer]]'' suite. It was originally commissioned for the British educational documentary film called ''Instruments of the Orchestra'' released on 29 November 1946, directed by [[Muir Mathieson]] and featuring the [[London Symphony Orchestra]] conducted by [[Malcolm Sargent]];<ref>[http://explore.bfi.org.uk/4ce2b69f17167 "Instruments of the Orchestra"], British Film Institute, accessed 24 May 2013</ref> Sargent also conducted the concert première on 15 October 1946 with the [[Royal Liverpool Philharmonic]] in the [[Philharmonic Hall, Liverpool]], England.
The work is one of the best-known pieces by the composer, and is often associated with two other works in the context of children's [[music education]]: [[Camille Saint-Saëns|Saint-Saëns]]' ''[[The Carnival of the Animals]]'' and [[Sergei Prokofiev|Prokofiev]]'s ''[[Peter and the Wolf]]''.{{citation needed|date = November 2013}}
This work, in the composer's own words, "is affectionately inscribed to the children of [[John Redcliffe-Maud, Baron Redcliffe-Maud|John]] and [[Jean Redcliffe-Maud|Jean Maud]]: [[Humphrey Maud|Humphrey]], Pamela, Caroline and Virginia, for their edification and entertainment".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=KX-zz5p-Fp0C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false "Essential Britten: A Pocket Guide for the Britten Centenary"], John Bridcut, accessed 14 January 2014</ref>
==Instrumentation== ''The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra'' is scored for symphony orchestra:
*''[[Woodwind instrument|Woodwinds]]'': [[piccolo]], 2 [[Western concert flute|flute]]s, 2 [[oboe]]s, 2 [[clarinet]]s in [[soprano clarinet|B flat and A]] and 2 [[bassoon]]s *''[[Brass instrument|Brass]]'': 4 [[French horn|horns]] in F, 2 [[trumpet]]s in C, 3 [[trombone]]s (2 [[tenor trombone|tenors]] and 1 [[bass trombone|bass]]) and [[Tuba|bass tuba]] *''[[Percussion]]'': [[timpani]], [[bass drum]], [[cymbal]]s, [[tambourine]], [[Triangle (musical instrument)|triangle]], [[snare drum]], [[cowbell]], [[xylophone]], [[castanet]]s, [[Gong|tamtam]], and [[Whip (percussion)|whip]] *''[[String instrument|Strings]]'': [[harp]], first and second [[violin]]s, [[viola]]s, [[cello]]s and [[double bass]]es
==Structure== The work is based on the [[Rondo|Rondeau]] from [[Henry Purcell]]'s [[incidental music]] to [[Aphra Behn]]'s ''[[Abdelazer]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lco.co.uk/concerts/programme-notes-archive/18-april-2013-programme-notes|accessdate=3 August 2013|publisher=London Chamber Orchestra|title=Programme Notes|date=18 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130804060800/http://www.lco.co.uk/concerts/programme-notes-archive/18-april-2013-programme-notes|archivedate=4 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and is structured, in accordance with the plan of the original documentary film, as a way of showing off the tone colours and capacities of the various sections of the orchestra.
In the introduction, the theme is initially played by the entire orchestra, then by each major family of instruments of the orchestra: first the woodwinds, then the [[brass instrument|brass]], then the [[string instrument|strings]], and finally by the percussion. Each [[variation (music)|variation]] then features a particular instrument in depth, generally moving through each family from high to low (the order of the families is slightly different from the introduction). So, for example, the first variation features the piccolo and flutes; each member of the woodwind family then gets a variation, ending with the bassoon; and so on, through the strings, brass, and finally the percussion.
After the whole orchestra has been effectively taken to pieces in this way, it is reassembled using an original [[fugue]] which starts with the piccolo, followed by all the woodwinds, strings, brass and percussion in turn. Once everyone has entered, the brass are re-introduced (with a strike on the tamtam) with Purcell's original melody.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lco.co.uk/concerts/special-events/20-march-2013-qmul/20-march-2013-programme-notes|accessdate=3 August 2013|publisher=London Chamber Orchestra|title=Programme Notes|date=20 March 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130804060802/http://www.lco.co.uk/concerts/special-events/20-march-2013-qmul/20-march-2013-programme-notes|archivedate=4 August 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The sections of the piece and instruments introduced by the variations are as follows.
;Theme: Allegro maestoso e largamente :[[Tutti]], [[woodwinds]], [[brass instrument|brass]], [[String instrument|strings]], then [[Percussion instrument|percussion]] ;Variation A: Presto :[[Piccolo]] and [[flute]] ;Variation B: Lento :[[Oboe]]s ;Variation C: Moderato :[[Clarinet]]s ;Variation D: Allegro alla marcia :[[Bassoon]]s ;Variation E: Brillante: alla polacca :Violins ;Variation F: Meno mosso :[[Viola]]s ;Variation G: Lusingando :Cellos ;Variation H: Cominciando lento ma poco a poco accel. al Allegro :[[Double bass]]es ;Variation I: Maestoso :[[Harp]] ;Variation J: L'istesso tempo :[[French horn|Horns]] ;Variation K: Vivace :Trumpets ;Variation L: Allegro pomposo :[[Trombone]]s and bass tuba ;Variation M: Moderato :Percussion ([[timpani]]; [[bass drum]] & [[cymbal]]s; [[tambourine]] & [[triangle (musical instrument)|triangle]]; [[snare drum]] & [[wood block]]; [[xylophone]]; [[castanets]] & [[tamtam]]; [[Clapper (musical instrument)#Whip/Slapstick|whip]]; percussion tutti) ;Fugue: Allegro molto
==Narration== The narration for the documentary film was written by [[Eric Crozier]], the producer of the first production of Britten's opera ''[[Peter Grimes]]'', and is sometimes spoken by the conductor or a separate speaker during performance of the piece. The composer also arranged a version without narration. The one without narration is more often recorded. The commentary often alters between recordings.
A new narration was written by Simon Butteriss for the Aldeburgh Festival and broadcast live by CBBC presenter Johny Pitts with the BBC Symphony Orchestra for the Britten 100 celebrations in 2013.
Comedian and author [[John Hodgman]] wrote a new narration of ''The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra'' in 2015 for a series of performances with the [[Boston Pops Orchestra|Boston Pops]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wgbh.org/articles/John-Hodgman-in-the-Young-Persons-Guide-10425|title=John Hodgman in the Young Person's Guide: Boston Pops: WCRB: WGBH|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WKuU2_Q7zH4|title=Excerpts from John Hodgman's Debut Narration with Boston Pops|first=|last=Boston Pops|date=14 May 2015|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/entertainment/music/guestlisted/2015/05/excerpts_from_john_hodgmans_debut_narration_with_boston_pops|title=Excerpts from John Hodgman's debut narration with Boston Pops|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} * [[Boosey & Hawkes]] No. 606. Benjamin Britten – The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra Opus 34. * [http://lso.co.uk/orchestra/history/lso-and-film-music.html History of the London Symphony Orchestra on Film]
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070412215059/http://www.carnegiehall.org/article/explore_and_learn/art_online_resources_listening_adventures.html Animated guide presented by Carnegie Hall] * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b01hjs0v BBC Radio 4 programme about the piece and the score manuscript]
